title: Student tricks online scammer into sending him £25
text:
Ross Walsh decided enough was enough when he received his third email from a scammer (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

A student sick of being targeted by online scammers decided to get his own back by tricking a fraudster into sending him £25 so he could donate it to charity.

When DJ Ross Walsh, 22, from Limerick, Ireland, received his third email from a fraudster purporting to be a ‘big business banker’ with a special offer, he decided he’d had enough.

After scammer, Solomon Gundi, emailed Ross asking for a £1,000 investment so the pair could become business partners, the student decided to go along with the charade.

A seemingly enthusiastic Ross told the fraudster he was so ‘delighted’ to receive the business proposal he would transfer £50,000 because European entrepreneurs ‘do things BIG’.

But when the huge sum didn’t land in Gundi’s account, he emailed to say perhaps there was a problem with the transfer but promised Ross he would make him rich.

Solomon Gundi emailed Ross with his big business proposal (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Ross decided to play along with the scam (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

The student said European entrepreneurs ‘go BIG’ (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

He pretended to send £50,000 to Gundi (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Unsurprisingly, Gundi didn’t receive any money (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Ross reassured Gundi that the bank feared their deal was a scam and he knew how to resolve the issue.

He told Gundi in order to ‘unfreeze the assets’, the bank would need to see a small sum of money entering Ross’s account and that £25 should be sufficient.

The student also advised Gundi that from now on they should speak in code, so the bank don’t block their big business deal.

In the ultimate twist of good karma, Gundi sent over the money and Ross immediately donated it to the Irish Cancer Society.

It appears this isn’t the first time Ross has played scammers for the greater good, after claiming Gundi’s payment as his ‘largest haul to date’.

But Ross assured him this was a minor blip (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

It seemed to work (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Gundi sent over £25 after falling for Ross’s explanation (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Ross used the cash to donate to charity (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

Ross’s final words to the scammer (Picture: Ross Walsh/Facebook)

The student shared screenshots of his email exchanges on his official DJ page, with the post garnering thousands of likes.

He wrote: ‘Checked my spam again and was greeted again with another business proposal which caught my attention.

‘Like the last 2 times I wanted to waste their time so they don’t waste anyone else’s or before they prey on a vulnerable person.

‘This is my largest haul to date a whopping £25. Went with a very James Veitch approach. Scammers 0 Ross 3. Solomon loves hurling.’

From now on, scammers will be thinking twice before they contact Ross with business proposals.

description: Ross Walsh, Limerick, Ireland, scammed the scammer into sending over money instead.
